body: `PHPStanReportParserTest` now uses simple string replacement.
I should verify it actually but I have not installed xdebug to my new pc yet. Just wait.
@junichi11 I tried, hopefuly it is OK.

I agree with Neil here. It looks like the plain "GPLvX-CPE" ist Category-X can be reevaluated, but that was a first "looks like it could be Category-A". However I can imaginge, that there are more strings attached and maybe we still need to be able to create binaries, that don't contain the GPLv2-CPE binaries.

In the mail from Roy there is a clear hint, the the PMC should also first discuss how this should be handled and I tend to agree.

First, just to make sure, I represent only myself personally here, and I am not a lawyer.

So, I think Roy's argument is, that the license of the resulting executable is (can be) ALv2, in which case we are fine, because Category A rules apply. While it would be awesome to have an entry in "resolved", I am not sure it is strictly necessary. In fact, I believe we are already doing something similar - the Windows launchers link against the standard libraries, which are (AFAIK) GPLv3 with an exception. (I don't want to pretend I can quantify how similar the exception are or are not.) And I believe the recommendation back then was to mark the whole launcher as ALv2, and this is what was done.

How to translate all this to NetBeans IDE as a whole modular application written in Java is (I think) the question now. And I do not have firm answers, but I assume this PR was meant to discuss aspects the PMC can discuss. OTOH, feel free to take it to the mailing list.

The specific hint about PMC was:

> The source of their work would still only be under GPL+CE and
would have to be entirely separate from our products. How you would
make sure of that is a PMC discussion.

We can discuss that as well, but especially in case of JavaFX, I am not sure how the sources for JavaFX and NetBeans could be seen to not be entirely separate.

What I like here is the use of the "nb" cluster. Unlike all other clusters, this one creates the application, that is Apache NetBeans IDE, and hence could be described as defining the "executable" (and it also physically includes the actual launcher/executable file). If that's a sufficient - not sure, but hope so.
@BradWalker You should update Travis config and GItHub Actions config to allow these use the new cache folder.
Has #2210 improved the behavior or are these changes still needed?

I've been told to switch the destination branch to `master`: done in d4a1f67

How shall we move on?

I believe the NetBeans IDE ZIP (& the installers) can be considered executable. The JavaFX NBMs still contain only the ".external" file - e..g. we don't distribute the GPLv2CPEx bits in the NBMs. Only in the ZIP - a case that the GPLv2CPEx explicitly allows and gives us permission to label the whole ZIP/Installers/Executables with Apache license.

Do we need to do more? Based on RMS's "printer story" I believe it is essential for any user of NetBeans to be able to fix a bug in GPLv2CPEx Apache NetBeans libraries ownself and use the patch for him and/or others. In the case of JavaFX it is trivial - the source is on Maven central next to the libraries.
I read the messages on legal as not yet decided. Its unfortunate, that the term "executable" is not defined. Before that happens and we have the full picture, I'd like not to rush things.

Not sure if it is applicable also here but usually a minimum size of the dialog can be defined.

OS distros usually define a place for cache files, which the IDE respects (e.g. ${user.home}/.cache

It would be preferable to figure that out (env var?) and use that.

As already pointed out by @timboudreau it looks that _NetBeans cache dir_ rather than _NetBeans user dir_ is better suited to hold cached data.

For example NetBeans cache dir on Linux is `$HOME/.cache/netbeans/<version>`.

If this cache is used during build the trailing `<version>` folder could be omitted.

Rather than using `Consumer` and `BiConsumer`, I'd suggest to create inner class `Controller` in `ProxyLookup` and add constructor that takes the `Controller`. The `Controller` would have public `setLookups` method. Kind of similar to `AbstractLookup` and its `Content`.

@tmysik Yes, it is valid.
Type `static` is subtype of `self`. Using `self` as native return type is still better than leaving it out completely.
It is similar case as when you use type `array` in formal parameter and then use `@param \DateTime[]` to indicate that array should contain `\DateTime` objects.

PHP 8 will have native `static` return type - https://wiki.php.net/rfc/static_return_type

I'm not sure I'm in love with that solution for the following reason:

ProxyLookup.Controller ctrl = new ProxyLookup.Controller();
ProxyLookup lookup1 = new Proxylookup(ctrl);
ProxyLookup lookup2 = new ProxyLookup(ctrl);

and what happens?

Not to mention that ProxyLookup.Controller will need internal fields to
hold any lookups set before it has been attached to a ProxyLookup, adding
to the footprint unnecessarily.

Seems clunkier while adding little value.

-Tim
